original_title: Sri Lanka state radio raises Rs1.5bn in land sales, to be used for restructuring, VRS
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – State-run Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation will use 1.5 billion rupees raised from land sales to other state agencies to restructure and fund a voluntary retirement scheme, Minister Vijitha Herath said.
A portion of SLBC land in Ekala had already been transferred to the Urban Development Authority for 1,286 million rupees.
The previous cabinet had decided to use the monies from this sale to restructure the loss-making state broadcasting body into a profitable institute.

525 million rupees of the sale proceeds has been received by the SLBC, of which 205 million rupees has been set aside as compensation for a voluntary retirement scheme for employees of the corporation, a cabinet statement said.
The Cabinet of Ministers has approved the proposal to implement 25 actions relevant to the modernization of SLBC using 145.72 million rupees from the remaining amount.
The SLBC lost 532 million rupees in 2023 and 235 million rupees in 2022 according to Finance Ministry data.
Another 2-acre land of a total 10 acres belonging to the SLBC in Ekala will be transferred to the CEB, for 320 million rupees.
This is for a grid substation to be built to provide continuous electricity supply for the Ekala industrial zone and based on the rising demand in the area, Minister Vijitha Herath said.

The current minority transition government came to power promising not to sell state assets for dirt cheap [kunu-kolleta] and criticized the past government for plans to restructure state owned enterprises.
In the past, VRS schemes have provided selected staff with a comfortable nest egg, while they are re-employed by the same companies on a contract basis. (Colombo/Oct15/2024)
